definition: (dialect) oneself/by oneself
self/oneself/from/since/naturally/surely
variant of 個|个[ge4]
individual/this/that/size/classifier for people or objects in general
variant of 人[ren2]/"person" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 10), occurring in 兒, 兀, 兄 etc
child/son
non-syllabic diminutive suffix/retroflex final

sentences.english: I felt uncomfortable, and even afraid, of going out by myself.
sentences.chinese: 我很是不爽，甚至都害怕自个儿出去买东西了。

sentences.english: She certainly knows better than to tackle such problems by herself.
sentences.chinese: 她那么明智的人当然不至于自个儿去解决这类问题。

sentences.english: He is in from height merely ice bewail, be at a loss unexpectedly rise.
sentences.chinese: 他只顾自个儿在冰上叹惜，竟不知所措起来。

sentences.english: Whatever you earn and loss you suck it up, SO it is big risk.
sentences.chinese: 赚了赔了都是您自个儿的，风险挺大。

sentences.english: A man's whole strength is required to successfully carry out these singular ascents .
sentences.chinese: 他得使出全身力气才能巧妙地自个儿直升上去。

sentences.english: "I am going to open the instrument, Eliza, and you know what follows."
sentences.chinese: “我去打开琴，伊丽莎，下文如何，你自个儿明白。”

sentences.english: Want son is in mind muggy during a lifetime from?
sentences.chinese: 难道要自个儿闷在心里一辈子啊？

sentences.english: I walked the streets, sneering at humans to myself.
sentences.chinese: 我走在大街上，自个儿在心底嘲笑这些人类。

sentences.english: Are you just going to stand there muttering to yourself?
sentences.chinese: 你打算站在那跟自个儿嘟囔个没完是吗？
一个人自个儿瞎琢磨的，叫犯贱。

sentences.english: Allow us to read the text alone.
sentences.chinese: 让我们自个儿朗读课文吧。

sentences.english: A package of razor blades doesn't run away and hide.
sentences.chinese: 一包刀片不会自个儿跑掉藏起来的。

definition: thus/in this way/like this
variant of 自個兒|自个儿[zi4 ge3 r5]
to have spare time/free from work/it's not important/it's nothing/never mind
(dialect) very
contraction of 不用[bu4 yong4]/need not/please don't
in good condition/perfectly good/carefully/well/thoroughly
size/height/stature
erhua variant of 哥們|哥们[ge1 men5]
erhua variant of 可勁|可劲[ke3 jin4]
I (northern dialects)
my old mother/I, this old woman/my old lady (colloquial)/maternal grandmother/midwife
vigorously/to the utmost/to the best of one's ability
to avoid/so as to save (money or time)
I/me/my/(often used in early vernacular literature)
I/me/we/my home/our house
to make a scene/to fool around/to behave foolishly
wife/young married woman
to ask for trouble/to bring misfortune on oneself
